DEBATE.TITLE: SYDNEY 2000 GAMES (INDICIA AND IMAGES) PROTECTION BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 30 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Sydney 2000 Games (Indicia and Images) Protection Bill 1996 is to protect the Sydney 2000 Olympics and Paralympic Games licensing revenue from being undermined by unauthorised use of the games indicia and images by corporate competitors of the official games sponsors. The bill will achieve this by regulating the use for commercial purposes of the indicia and images associated with the games.

The hosting of the Olympic Games in the year 2000 is an event of great significance to Australia. It provides a unique opportunity to demonstrate to the world this country's skills, talents, environment and achievements. Preparations for the games have proceeded in a very professional manner. This has been under the guidance of the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games, SOCOG, and with a high level of cooperation between the New South Wales state government and the Commonwealth government. The organisation of the games is an inspiring venture and the public interest in every aspect of the build‐up is intense.

The government will ensure that the cooperation which has marked the first two years of preparation for the games continues. We will continue to cooperate with SOCOG and other agencies and organisations involved in organising the games. This cooperation is to ensure that Australia's competitors in the games are given every opportunity to succeed and that the games will be an outstanding success. The task of organising the games is very large and complex. It is also very expensive. As the host nation for the year 2000 games, Australia will be expending considerable sums of money in the lead‐up to the year 2000 for the construction of facilities and infrastructure, organisation and marketing.

The cost of staging the Sydney 2000 Olympic and Paralympic Games is estimated to be around $2 billion. It will be shared between the organising committees, SOCOG, and the Sydney Paralympic Organising Committee, SPOC, the government of NSW and the Commonwealth government. The Commonwealth government's overall budgetary contribution to the games will exceed $400 million. Sources of revenue to meet the costs of the Sydney Games include the sale of television rights, ticket sales and the licensing of the right to use the games indicia and images. After television rights, licensing or sponsorship rights are the most important source of revenue to meet the costs of organising and staging the games. It is expected that the revenue raised from official sponsorships would need to be of the order of $700 million to meet the revenue budget of the games.

The ability of SOCOG and SPOC to attract sponsors will depend to a large extent on the degree of exclusivity afforded to the licensed indicia and images. Official sponsors recognise the commercial value of associating themselves with events of the magnitude of the Olympic Games and are willing to pay considerable sums of money to use the words and symbols associated with the Olympics. In this regard, I note that SOCOG has announced that Telstra and IBM are to jointly contribute more than $100 million. They are the first members of Team Millennium, the corporate sponsorship program for the Sydney 2000 Games. The agreement was negotiated in anticipation of the strengthening of the legislative protection of intellectual property rights associated with the Sydney Games.

Ambush marketing, however, has the capacity to seriously erode the official sponsorship revenue if not stopped or minimised. Ambush marketing is the unauthorised association of businesses with the marketing of an event, such as the Sydney Games, without paying for marketing rights. Typically it is the competitors of official sponsors of major sporting events that engage in these activities. Australian and overseas experience of recent Olympic Games has highlighted the threat that uncontrolled ambush marketing activities can pose to the value of exclusive licensing rights on Olympic Games symbols and indicia. Because ambush marketing can be very effective in creating a perception that the free‐rider is in fact an official sponsor, it can dissuade official sponsors from continuing their association with the Olympics. It can also substantially reduce the amount that sponsors are prepared to pay for the rights.

The preservation of sponsorship revenue is fundamental to achieving a sound financial outcome for the games thereby ensuring the least call on the public purse. The government of NSW has underwritten and bears full responsibility for any deficit between the games income and expenditure. The protection of official sponsorships against ambush marketing is therefore critical.

The terms of the host city contract for the Sydney 2000 Olympics present obligations to the signatories for these matters. The host city, the New South Wales government, the Australian Olympic Committee and SOCOG are obliged to ensure that there are no other marketing programs in the host country which will have an impact on the games marketing program.

The measures introduced to the chamber today are the result of a series of initiatives from the coalition parties. In 1994, the Liberal and National parties initiated an inquiry into the effects of ambush marketing on sponsorship revenue for the games. This followed early indications of serious problems for the organisers, the sponsors, and therefore ultimately the taxpayers.

In February 1995 we announced we would support legislation to provide property rights in the words and expressions and names of bodies associated with the 2000 Games and the Paralympics. In March 1995 the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs unanimously supported this position. The AOC, SOCOG and the previous New South Wales government had called for this legislation from the time of awarding of the games to Sydney.

The previous government introduced the Sydney 2000 Games (Indicia and Images) Protection Bill 1995 into the Senate on 29 November 1995. It did not introduce it in time to make it law before the proroguing of parliament. This has created the very real risk of part of SOCOG's marketing revenue being siphoned off, with the cost being borne indirectly by Australian sport and the taxpayer.

The bill I am now introducing is essentially the same as the bill introduced into the Senate last year with the exception of three minor amendments. The amendments clarify the legislation and provide additional protection in accordance with the organising committees' wishes. It gives additional protection to that provided by the Olympic Insignia Protection Act 1987 which protects Olympic symbols such as the five rings and the designs of the Olympic flame and torch. That act was amended in 1994 to extend the protection available.

The new legislation will protect the use of a wide range of words and expressions against ambush marketing during the lead up to and including the Sydney Games. It will pick up most of the recommendations made in March 1995 by the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee in its report entitled Cashing in on the Sydney Olympics: protecting the Sydney Olympic Games from ambush marketing. The bill will have a limited period of application and will cease to have effect after 31 December 2000.

I will now briefly outline significant features of this legislation. The bill seeks to provide protection to indicia encompassing words and expressions associated with the Olympic and Paralympic Games. Words and phrases such as `Olympic', `Olympiad', `Paralympic', `Paralympiad', `Sydney 2000', `Sydney Games', `Millennium Games', `Team Millennium' and `Summer Games' will be protected against unlicensed commercial use under this legislation. Particular word combinations will also be protected under this legislation. These include, for example, any combinations of the words `Olympics', `Olympian', `Paralympics' and `Paralympian' with words, numbers or phrases such as `Sydney', `2000', `Two Thousand', `Games', `Medals', `Gold', `Silver', `Bronze', `Green and Gold' and `Sponsor'.

In addition to protecting particular words, numbers and expressions, the bill also seeks to provide protection to certain images that in the circumstances of their presentation suggest, or are likely to suggest, a connection with the Sydney 2000 Olympic or Paralympic Games. These images may be either visual or aural representations. The rights in the above protected indicia and images vest with SOCOG and SPOC. These two bodies have the power to use and to license others to use the indicia and images identified in the legislation for commercial purposes.

To constitute use for commercial purposes, the Sydney Games indicia or images must be applied to a person's goods or services for advertising or promotional purposes, or for enhancing the demand for the goods or services, and in a manner which would suggest that the person is or has been a sponsor of, or is or has been providing other support for, the Sydney 2000 Olympic or Paralympic Games or both. That is, a person who sells or promotes their goods or services by using any of the protected indicia or images in a way that would be reasonably understood as suggesting that the person is claiming sponsorship of, or to be providing other support for the games, would be using them for commercial purposes.

In order to enable the public to be aware of the identity of those licensed to use the Sydney Games indicia and images, a register will be established and maintained by SOCOG. It will be made accessible to members of the public at its office in Sydney. The register will also be accessible throughout Australia at state offices of the Australian Industrial Property Organisation. An entry in the register will include details such as the name and principal place of business of the licensed user, the Sydney Games indicia and images that the licensed user may use, and the circumstances in which the indicia and images may be used. A person whose name is entered on the register is to be taken to be a licensed user of the Sydney Games indicia or images specified in that entry. A document certified by the chief executive officer of SOCOG is evidence that the particulars set out in the document are entered in the register.

This bill, however, is not about placing an absolute fetter on any use of the protected Sydney Games indicia and images. The government recognises that the preservation of sponsorship revenue is essential to achieving a good budget outcome for the games. But the fundamental rights of the community to freedom of expression must be respected, particularly in relation to words that have passed into common usage. It must therefore be emphasised that restrictions on the usage of the Sydney Games indicia and images will apply only to unlicensed commercial use of the protected indicia and images.

Moreover, it is made clear in the bill that the legislation is not intended to affect the working of many aspects of everyday business. It is recognised that some individuals and corporations already use the indicia prescribed in the legislation in conjunction with their goods and services. There are, for example, goods and services which either have the trademark `Olympic' or include the word `Olympic'—such as Olympic tyres and Olympic Airways. This legislation is not about stopping traders who have been using these indicia and images for years from continuing that use. The established rights of owners of registered trademarks or designs containing those indicia and images remain unaffected, so long as the trademarks or designs are not used in a way so as to imply a connection to the games.

The use of the Sydney Games indicia or images solely for the purposes of providing information, or for the purposes of criticism or review, is not of itself prohibited. Examples of such provision of information include the reporting of news and presentation of current affairs, the factual description of goods or services provided by a business, such as stating that accommodation is available at a hotel that is located near the Olympic site or the factual statements by an athlete to promote their own achievements. Examples of criticism and review are those which are likely to appear in newspapers, magazines or similar periodicals, in a radio or television broadcast, or in a cinematographic film.

The government recognises that the reasonable needs of sporting bodies in relation to fund raising for and promotion of their preparation of athletes and teams for the Sydney Olympic and Paralympic Games should be allowed to continue. Those reasonable needs could involve use of the Sydney Games indicia or images for the purposes of providing factual information. As I have just explained, the bill is not intended to affect this type of use. In the interests of clarity and certainty, the government believes it would be desirable for sporting bodies to negotiate memoranda of understanding with SOCOG to cover their proposed use of the Sydney Games indicia and images. The Australian Sports Commission has negotiated such an agreement.

While strategies are being devised to ensure that new business opportunities will flow to all industries, including small and medium enterprises, the tourism industry in particular has the greatest contribution to make in securing and dispersing spin‐off benefits from the games. It has therefore been a major concern that the legislation does not inhibit the capacity of tourism marketing bodies and individual firms to undertake advertising and promotional activities which complement the role of SOCOG and the Olympic bodies.

The provision of the information clause, which I have just mentioned, accommodates tourism marketing. That is, tourism marketing involving the provision of information that is both generic tourism promotion by official marketing bodies and factual statements about products and services by individual firms, should not require SOCOG's approval. Those tourism businesses wishing to become directly associated with the games will need to apply to SOCOG. The impact of the legislation on tourism marketing will be monitored.

The bill provides various remedies to SOCOG, SPOC and licensed users to enforce their rights in relation to the Sydney Games indicia and images. Thus, where an unlicensed user uses Sydney Games indicia or images in contravention of the bill, SOCOG, SPOC or a relevant licensed user may bring an action against the unlicensed user. The remedies available under the bill include injunctions, damages and corrective advertising. However, in addition to those remedies, the courts have the discretion to provide remedies under any law (whether a law of the Commonwealth, a state or a territory) that confers any rights or powers on SOCOG, SPOC or a licensed user. Most notable in this regard are the remedies provided under the Trade Practices Act 1974 in relation to engaging in conduct that is misleading or deceptive.
The bill also includes appropriate customs measures to limit the possibility of the importation of goods which seek to ambush the games marketing.

The ongoing cost to the government of administering this legislation will be minimal. The Australian Customs Service will be able to carry out the measures of this legislation relating to the monitoring of imported goods at the barrier within their existing resources. It is likely that the increased security of the Olympic 2000 indicia and images will enhance SOCOG's and SPOC's capacity to ensure the financial viability of the 2000 Games through its marketing program.

I believe that the bill introduces significant protection for the Sydney Games indicia and images. The protection provided by this bill will both complement and enhance the protective measures already in place under Australia's current intellectual property laws to ensure, to the extent possible, that a good budget outcome is achieved for the Sydney 2000 Games. I commend this bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) for reading the second reading speech again on the Sydney 2000 Games (Indicia and Images) Protection Bill 1996. Before I make some comments about that, Mr Deputy Speaker, I make a suggestion for you to take up with the Speaker. I should have made this suggestion previously. When the bill has already passed through the Senate, perhaps the opportunity could be pursued for second reading speeches to be incorporated in Hansard in the House of Representatives. It might save the honourable minister's time and those of us who are going to speak will know that the debate has already occurred in the other place. We can get hold of the legislation from there and prepare our response accordingly.
—I thank the honourable member and I will certainly convey his views to the Speaker.

—You are very kind. Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The opposition does not oppose the Sydney 2000 Games (Indicia and Images) Protection Bill 1996. In fact, we wholeheartedly embrace it. As the honourable minister indicated, this particular bill with three minor changes in fact had been put before the parliament just before it was prorogued last year, and regrettably did not therefore receive passage. As a result, it has had to be put in again now. Clearly, because of all the reasons that the minister has espoused, it is a bill that should be supported.

SPEECH.PARA: I do want to pick up on a couple of the points that are there, though, because I do think it is extremely important that we not understate one or two very significant matters associated with the year 2000 Olympics in Sydney. Very recently, I had the opportunity to visit the Homebush site. If members of this parliament get the opportunity to organise a visit to the Olympic site at Homebush, I commend the visit. It is extremely enlightening to see the work that has already taken place and that is ongoing. It is a real eye‐opener to look at the plans that are in place and to look at the magnitude of the proposal which Australia was successful in obtaining.

BREAK.PARA: That said, one of the things which concerns me a touch when talking about the Olympics, about marketing and about why we need this legislation in place to protect the indicia and the images associated with the Olympic Games is that maybe we place too much emphasis on the commercial aspect of the games. I had the opportunity to talk recently to Lois Appleby from the paralympic organisation here in Australia and she was telling me she has just come back from Atlanta. She said, `You would be surprised. The word "athlete" was hardly ever mentioned. What they were concerned about in Atlanta was Coca‐Cola sponsorship or sponsorship by AT&T or sponsorship by Nike or Reebok, or whoever it might be that has gotten that sponsorship, and the athletes hardly rate a mention at the moment in Atlanta.' I think to some extent we might tend to lose sight of the fact that the modern Olympics are the ultimate test of the athleticism of men and women from around this globe brought together in the summer Olympics in a spirit of peace and harmony but certainly fierce competition. Perhaps it would not hurt for a few of us at least to continue to remind people that that is the case.

But it still is important to protect the revenue raising ability of the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games and also the Sydney Paralympics Organising Committee and their opportunities to maximise revenue from the Olympics in the year 2000. It is important, because of what we have seen in past Olympic Games, for that to occur with a legislative base. There is no doubt that ambush marketing is something which could have a detrimental effect on the revenue capacity of the games and its organisers and therefore a consequential effect on whether the games are seen to be successful in terms of a dollar making ability.

It is said that when the bid was put forward by Sydney, with the support of the Australian government and of course the New South Wales government, very tight constraints were imposed on that bid in terms of budgeting. Part of that budgeting went to the issue of revenue that could be raised through the licensing of particular companies to sell products which were endorsed by the organising committees and which clearly carried some identifying logo relevant to the Olympic Games. Ambush marketing is defined as the unauthorised association by businesses of their names, brands, products or services with a sports event or competition through any one or more of a wide range of marketing activities. It is unauthorised in the sense that the controller of the commercial rights in such events, usually the relevant governing body, has neither sanctioned nor licensed the association itself or through its commercial agents.

That is really what our concern is about in respect of this legislation. What we are concerned about is the fact that the Olympic Games in Sydney are estimated to cost between $2 billion and $3 billion, and there is some $700 million expected to be raised from commercial sponsorship. That commercial sponsorship is going to be an underpinning feature of meeting budget commitments and ensuring that the facilities that are going to have to be built on the way through are in fact ready in time and are leading edge facilities. That is happening now. As I said, take the opportunity to go and have a look at what is happening at Homebush and you will see for yourselves.

Some licences have been announced already, particularly for a whole range of clothing, from underwear through to tracksuits. A whole range of preferred suppliers have been licensed by SOCOG at the present time. I think that is appropriate. That shows why you need to protect those people that have been given a licence to manufacture products and put the Olympic logos on them for Sydney and have some revenue raised in that respect. But it goes further. As we know, large commercial sponsorships from organisations, whether they be telecommunications carriers, banks, airlines or whatever, are just around the corner.

Clearly, people are paying substantial amounts of money to be the up‐front premier sponsors of the Sydney Olympics, and they want recognition for it. They are not going to throw hundreds of millions of dollars into this to let somebody else come along and by some sleight of hand, or by the use of the Olympic rings, or the torch, or by talking about gold or silver sponsorships—as the minister outlined in his second reading speech—having a de facto sponsorship and therefore giving the indication in the minds of some that they are official sponsors. Only the ones that are licensed by the organisations mentioned have that responsibility; only they have the right to market themselves in that way.

There are some exemptions contained within this legislation, and the minister mentioned those. I want to reinforce the point that businesses already using prescribed words or symbols—such as Olympic Airways—can continue to do so providing, of course, that they do not link themselves specifically to these games. They are permitted the use of prescribed words in news and current affairs reporting. Factual information, tour operators and hotels are the examples that the minister used. I think that is absolutely correct. You cannot stop the genuine need for news broadcasts to refer to the Sydney Olympics or to talk about it and, clearly, this bill makes the necessary exemptions.

But what we do not want is to get into some of the ambush marketing that occurred in some previous Olympics. For example, the Nike‐Reebok sneakers war during the 1992 Barcelona summer Olympics saw members of the gold medal winning USA basketball dream team, with personal sponsorships from Nike, threatening to boycott the medal presentation rather than wear the official team uniform featuring Nike's rival, Reebok. That sort of thing should not be allowed to happen again.

During the Barcelona Olympics General Motors Holden advertised that it would give a golden Holden to any gold medal winner, despite Toyota's exclusive deal of sponsorship. These are some of the examples where I think it is important that protection is given to those people and those large businesses that are putting many tens of millions of dollars, if not hundreds of millions, towards the Sydney Olympics.

The question about memorandums of understanding being signed between sports and organisations has some merit, and I think the minister is absolutely right to highlight that. There are already some examples with the Australian Olympic Committee where that is happening, and I commend the minister's action as well.

I will not delay consideration or passage of this bill. As I said, the opposition wholeheartedly supports it. It had its genesis when we were the government in the last parliament, and regrettably, it did not get passed in time. It has a sunset clause; it will conclude at the conclusion of the Olympic Games and I think that that is appropriate.

I would like to conclude by commending both John Coates, from the Australian Olympic Committee, and Michael Knight, the minister in New South Wales responsible for the Olympics. Those two have the highest public profile when it comes to the Olympics at this stage. They have negotiated an extremely fair and reasonable set of circumstances for year 2000 Olympics, particularly in respect of the matter of ongoing sponsorship. Michael Knight has one eye, quite obviously, on the finances of the state government of New South Wales—as any responsible minister would have—and John Coates, an absolutely dynamic, committed individual for the Australian Olympic movement for many years, has his eye on protecting Australia's Olympic interests into the future.

Both of them have been accommodating, and both have accommodated the need for commercial sponsorship. I think that this bill, which was discussed previously with the organising committees and which has been discussed before this parliament, is something which reflects very well on the New South Wales government and, in particular, on Michael Knight, the Australian Olympic Committee and John Coates. And we should not forget the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games and the Sydney Paralympics Organising Committee. Those people also have been well and truly involved in the negotiations on what the structure of this bill should be and the way in which the outcomes of the bill, in terms of protection of sponsorship, will enhance those organisations. They have been given the primary responsibility for ensuring that the Olympic 2000 games are successful. They need to be successful for Australia for all the reasons that we know. Not only do the games give us a chance to showcase our own Olympic athletic prowess, but they also—as the minister at the table would know—give us that opportunity between now and then, and subsequently, to market Australia more broadly as a destination for international tourists.

We have to make sure that we get it right and that we turn on games the likes of which the world has never seen. I think we can. After all, it is going to be in one of the best cities in the world. I think we would all agree with that. Even my Tasmanian colleague, the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government (Mr Warwick Smith), would agree with that. I think it is important that we ensure that this legislation gets a speedy passage through the House. I wish it success.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr WARWICK SMITH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Shadow Minister for Sport and Tourism, the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Martin), for his recognition of the fact that I think Sydney is a great city. I do, in fact, think it is a great city—second only, of course, to Launceston. I can see that the member for Denison (Mr Kerr) has been putting in a bid for Hobart.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity to speak on the Sydney 2000 Games (Indicia and Images) Protection Bill in my capacity as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games, in which capacity I have an overarching responsibility for all matters Olympic as we go forward, and also in my capacity as Minister for Sport.

The Sydney Olympic and Paralympic Games are already a major focus for sports development in Australia. This focus is not only on Olympic sports and elite Olympic athletes; it is also proving to be the focus for grassroots participation development and in many cases for non‐Olympic sports. We ought not to forget that.

The sporting community as a whole is excited about the Olympics and enthusiastic about the contribution the games will make to the development of sport in our country. The whole community shares this enthusiasm. It is important for Australia and Australian sport that these games are a success. The commitment by the shadow minister and the work of others whom he mentioned are certainly recognised.

One of the critical factors in the success of the games is the ability of the organisers, SOCOG and the Sydney Paralympic Organising Committee, known as SPOC, to raise the funds necessary to host the games. That is certainly a massive task. The budget for simply hosting the games is nearly $2 billion—not including construction of facilities. Of that, SOCOG is looking to raise somewhere in the vicinity of $650 million from official games sponsors, licensing and marketing. If SOCOG falls short of raising enough money to host the games, then the New South Wales taxpayers will be required to foot the bill. SOCOG's ability to meet the target relies to a large extent on the degree of exclusivity an official sponsor will gain over games indicia and images. That is the reason for this bill, which enjoys very strong bipartisan support.

My colleague the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) went into some of the detail of the legislation. I shall not traverse that same territory. Let me refer to ambush marketing, which is the unauthorised association of businesses with the marketing of an event. Typically, the ambush marketer seeks to gain some benefit by suggesting that it is associated with the event without paying for those rights. It is emerging as a bit of a problem in Atlanta already, I understand. We want to try to avoid that problem occurring here. Ambush marketing can have a severe impact on exclusivity and consequently on the ability of SOCOG to raise the necessary funds.

In keeping with our strong commitment to support the Sydney Olympic Games, the coalition recognised, as did the former government, that legislation was necessary to protect the Sydney Olympics from ambush marketing. As early as February 1995, we announced that we would support legislation to protect the games from ambush marketing. Our 1996 sports policy committed the government to `enact strong and effective Olympic anti‐ambush marketing legislation in consultation with the Australian Olympic Committee.' I am pleased to say that this legislation implements our election commitment and mirrors almost exactly the draft legislation that the previous government put forward. Those consultations have been extremely positive. I hope that this is the beginning of a very positive and cooperative relationship at all levels of government and with all in the broader Olympic family as we all work as a nation to deliver a very successful games in the year 2000.

The minister covered most of the detail of the legislation, and I do not propose to repeat those details. Naturally, however, with the games four years away, the situation is still evolving. The government is discussing with SOCOG and other parties some additional requests for protection. This may result in further amendments to the legislation being required to be brought to this place. Despite the possible need for later amendments, it was clear that the need to have protection in place prior to the Atlanta games made the immediate introduction of this legislation necessary. So we are particularly pleased to be dealing with that matter today and we are pleased that the opposition has already signalled its strong support. I am confident that the government's prompt action on the legislation will put the Sydney games organisers in the best possible position to secure the revenue needed to finance the games. That is an issue that will be concerning all of us. This is a very vital piece of legislation to enable them to do that.

Perhaps the most important issue and the greatest challenge for the government was to draft legislation which would give SOCOG and SPOC the protection they deserve without producing unintended consequences. The intention is quite clear: unscrupulous people should not be able to cash in on the Olympics when they have made no contribution to supporting the event. The official sponsors and licensees need to be sure that they are not going to have their marketing advantage or their market taken from them. This goes for the biggest sponsor in the corporate category right through to the person producing Sydney Olympics pens.

BREAK.PARA: However, as sports minister, I believe it was also important to ensure that the legislation did not unduly restrict the legitimate activities of sporting organisations and individual athletes. For an athlete, a blanket restriction on the use of the words `Olympic', `Olympian' or `Olympic gold medallist', for example, might have serious detrimental effects. Most Olympic athletes make huge financial sacrifices to get to the top of their sport. Very few have time to undertake normal work and, as a result, most defer their careers and their financial security for many years.

For those athletes, the opportunity to gain sponsorship or market themselves as Olympic athletes brings a small recompense for the years of effort they have put in. Very few athletes have the stature or earning potential of, say, a Kieren Perkins but, as an example, just imagine how his earning potential would be affected if he were prohibited from promoting himself as an Olympic gold medallist.

As a result of the involvement of the Australian Sports Commission in the development of the legislation, I am confident that the rights of athletes will be preserved by the legislation. Under the legislation, athletes will be able to make a factual statement of their performance or achievements, subject to any other agreements they might sign. This means that an athlete who is a member of the Atlanta Olympic Games team will be able to describe himself or herself as an Olympian or an Olympic athlete and, if that athlete is fortunate enough to win a gold medal, as an Olympic gold medallist.

Sporting organisations also had the potential to be affected by the legislation. The Olympic sporting organisations, for example, may have perfectly legitimate uses for words such as `Olympic' or `Olympic team'. Once again, these organisations will be able to make factual statements. Olympic sporting organisations are already obliged by an Australian Olympic Committee by‐law to observe certain restrictions in the use of Olympic words and symbols. As a result, this legislation should not prove unduly restrictive on the activities of Olympic sporting organisations. The government was obviously also concerned to ensure that the Australian Sports Commission and particularly the Australian Institute of Sport were able to continue their legitimate promotion and fundraising activity in the lead‐up to the games.

The government, through the Australian Sports Commission, is making by far the biggest financial contribution to the development of our Olympic athletes. The $135 million Olympic athlete program, combined with other funding, is crucial for the development of our team. It is reasonable to expect that the commission should be able to gain credit for its role and its expertise. In addition, the ASC raises approximately $10 million per annum from a combination of program revenue, other funding and sponsorships to supplement government funding. The government believes the ASC should be able to continue to attract sponsor support, and should not be unduly restricted by the legislation.

In the discussions which led to this legislation, it was clear that some uses the AIS might have wished to make of protected indicia or images might have constituted a breach of the legislation. The AIS may, for example, wish to state that it is `training athletes for the Sydney 2000 Games'—a factual statement, but one which might have breached the legislation. To ensure that the Australian Sports Commission's legitimate uses are protected, the commission has negotiated with SOCOG a memorandum of understanding governing the use of protected indicia and images.

The MOU sets out the purposes and circumstances under which the commission can use protected indicia or images. It also includes a dispute resolution procedure in the unlikely event that a disagreement should arise. The MOU has continued the very positive and constructive working relationship which has developed between the Australian Sports Commission and SOCOG, a relationship which I am confident will continue over the next four years as the government works with SOCOG to ensure that the Sydney Olympic Games are a success.

The legislation is a tangible sign of the government's commitment to ensuring that the Sydney 2000 Games are a success. It adds to a broader range of assistance that the government is currently providing. As Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games, I have as one of my tasks to be involved in the coordination of the Commonwealth's involvement in the games. My appointment by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to this position, in addition to being Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government, is another important sign of the government's commitment to having a cooperative, coordinated approach to all that is going to be required to ensure that the games are a success.

TALK.START.PARA: —An excellent choice, too.

—Thank you very much, Mr Slipper. The range of assistance from the Commonwealth is very broad. Apart from financial assistance of $150 million, paid already by agreement between both major parties in this country for construction of facilities, $135 million for the preparation of athletes—which I have already mentioned—and $25 million towards staging the Paralympics, the Commonwealth is providing assistance with land for the Olympic village, drug testing, security, immigration, Customs and quarantine, health care, coin issue, communications and transport, and promotion of Australia.

BREAK.PARA: I predict that, over the period, very few areas of government will remain untouched by games activity and there needs to be a positive approach from all of us. I hope to ensure also that very few Australians will remain untouched by the overall Olympic experience. We need to ensure that it is not just Sydney that is going to see the benefit of the games.

The bill we are debating today will help to ensure that the staging of the games themselves will be a success. The government's commitment to Olympic athlete development will help to ensure that our athletes' performances will be successful. The third element of a successful games is to ensure that they produce benefits for all Australians. Later this year the government will announce how it is to implement its 2000 Plus election commitment. 2000 Plus will ensure that Australians in all states and territories benefit from Sydney hosting the 2000 Games.

I indicated when I commenced my remarks that the 2000 Games were proving to be a focus for the whole sporting community. The challenge is to utilise the focus on 2000 to ensure that, after 2000, we have a legacy of a fitter, more active society, a more professional sports industry and a range of ongoing economic and social benefits. These games will be a wonderful experience for all Australians and for the sporting community in particular. I am pleased that, through this bill, the government will be making a very substantial contribution to ensuring that the games are a success, and doing so in a very timely fashion in advance of the Atlanta Games.

I congratulate my colleague the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) for the work he and his department have done in putting together this piece of legislation which is quite complex. I also thank the opposition shadow spokesman, and the opposition generally, for the support they have given; originally, of course, it was their bill. I also congratulate—as did the shadow minister—the work of SOCOG who are tasked with a major undertaking on behalf of the nation, the government of New South Wales, the minister, Mr Knight—who also has a major task—the Australian Olympic Committee and Mr John Coates who, incidentally, is chef de mission for the Atlanta Games and also deputy chair of the Australian Sports Commission. There are very good and positive links between the sporting funding arrangements federally and the Olympic Committee.

I also congratulate all the other Commonwealth departments and the members of the special group within the Prime Minister's department who work with me on dealing with all the other matters that need to be dealt with for the very constructive way that we have undertaken a long and often complex negotiation on this particular legislation. It augurs well for a very positive approach to all the necessary difficulties and issues that we are going to need to address as we go forward to the year 2000 and the Olympic Games. I, too, commend the bill to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr, Duncan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to make what I intend to be a short contribution to this debate on the Sydney 2000 Games (Indicia and Images) Protection Bill 1996. I do so because I think the balance has been struck in a way which is quite defensible. It enables protection of the commercial sponsors of the Olympic Games, but does not include some of the provisions that might have been thought to offend against the rights of individual athletes and critics and others who may wish to engage in some debate about the sporting event, in a way that was the case with the bicentennial legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I have taken the opportunity to speak in this debate because I have a small personal history in the litigation that was conducted against the bicentennial legislation. At the time before my election in 1987, I spent some period as principal solicitor for the Aboriginal Legal Service. They were under instructions from an Aboriginal small business person who wanted to make certain statements on tee‐shirts he was manufacturing. The statements expressed some antagonism towards the spirit of the bicentennial, and pointed out that, as well as the 200 years of European settlement in Australia which the nation was celebrating, there was a period of 200 years of dispossession which Aboriginal Australians were concerned about.

Many of the ways in which the bicentennial act had been constructed would have prohibited the use of free speech and the use of expressions in common use. I was responsible for drafting the action and for appearing in the High Court before the then Chief Justice Sir Harry Gibbs. But by the time the case actually came on to the final determination I had become a member of parliament, and I was spared having to agitate for the case before the full court of the High Court, which heard it.

The points which we had raised, however, were successful in Davis v. Commonwealth, which is reported in 63 ALR 35. It is an interesting case, because the High Court, in a sense, anticipates its later decisions in terms of implied freedoms of speech—doctrines which have been the subject of some considerable controversy since that time. But, whatever the merits or otherwise of that stream of judicial law making, it is appropriate to reflect on the substance of what the court said, which is that it is inappropriate for legislation to go beyond what is a legitimate extension of the Commonwealth's interests in providing the lawful and appropriate protection, in the commercial sense, of the symbols.

I am pleased at the balance that the bill has established. As the minister indicated, this is legislation that was introduced by the former government and has been picked up—without any change at all—by the incoming government. It will prevent abuse of the commercial interests of those persons participating as sponsors in the Olympic Games. But it will not have the far reach of previous attempts to protect symbols, which were brought undone in the Davis v. Commonwealth case, for example, during the bicentennial.

BREAK.PARA: In conclusion, I might say that the victory that my clients had in Davis v. Commonwealth was entirely pyrrhic. By the time the High Court had decided its case, the bicentennial year had concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It may seem a bit odd to some for a member from Townsville, in North Queensland, to be up here talking about the Sydney 2000 Olympics. But it is important not to lose sight of the fact that, while Sydney will be hosting the games, all Australians must get behind the effort to ensure that it is a success.
—There will be common benefits.

—That is right. One of the areas where the Australian public can get behind the national Olympic effort is in the policing of the anti‐ambush marketing laws spelt out in the Sydney 2000 Games (Indicia and Images) Protection Bill 1996. This bill reflects one of the great features of Australian culture and society: having a fair go. With so much potential investment in the commercial sponsorship side of the Sydney Olympics—an expected $700 million—it is only fair that we do the best we can to ensure the commercial sponsors are given a fair go for their dollars. If we were to open the Olympic name and symbol to everyone to capitalise on we would very quickly lose the meaning behind the name and the meaning behind the symbol. It would become cheap, commercial and, ultimately, of no use to anyone.

SPEECH.PARA: Going to a rugby league match today is almost like sitting at home watching it on television; commercials blare out over loudspeakers and giant video screens broadcast ads to the crowd during half‐time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The commercials are better than the game.

—Yes, probably, Mr Martin. Half‐time breaks are generally brought to you by one group or another, as are the man of the match, try of the match, most valuable player and so on. The Olympic Games are big business and there can be no doubt about it. But it does not have to become overcommercialised; that will cheapen the event. I smiled to myself when I went through the submission prepared by the New South Wales government and the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games when this bill was in its infancy. In their appendix they list a range of business names that have been applied for since 1993 when Sydney won the bid to host the games. At the top of the list is the business name `Sydney 2000 Olympic Condoms'. I am no advertising whiz but I can imagine the advertising campaign that would have been based around the Olympic motto `citius, altius, fortius' or `swifter, higher, stronger'. It does not take much of an imagination to see what they probably had in mind.

SPEECH.PARA: Unlike the upcoming Atlanta Olympics, where the corporate dollar funds the event almost 100 per cent, the Sydney Olympics will be funded to a large extent by the taxpayer. The New South Wales state government has agreed to pick up the shortfall in funding for the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games. With taxpayers already footing part of the Olympic bill, I am sure they will not be pleased if we do not ensure that sponsors maximise returns on their investments and minimise the chance of further demands on the state or federal governments.

What we should be trying to do in Australia is to encourage sponsorship investment in sporting events. Why should the taxpayer always have to carry a large part of the bill? Tight laws protecting or limiting the use of key words, phrases and images associated with the Sydney Olympics encourage and protect that investment. Estimates suggest that about 1.4 million visitors will pass through Atlanta next month for the Olympics there; thousands of millions more will be watching the games on television worldwide. It is a very tempting advertising market and the potential rewards for successfully tapping it are huge. No doubt the temptation will prove too much for some and they will try to make a serious dollar or two by illegally associating themselves with the Olympic Games or the Olympic symbol.

The Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games is awarding 45 product licences under a $1 billion retail and marketing deal. Late last month the committee awarded the first seven licences; the top sponsors invested about $40 million each for exclusive product rights. Each of the companies is expected, according to the Australian, to generate about $400 million in retail sales in the run‐up to the Sydney Games. The games organising committee estimates that the sale of lapel pins alone for the Sydney 2000 Games could be up to 20 million units. The committee will be taking a 15 per cent cut from the revenue; this is approximately $50 to $60 million, depending on the final gross.

Senator Kemp said, in the second reading of the bill, that the revenue raised from official sponsorship would need to be of the order of $700 million to be in line with budget expectations for the games. In July 1994, the New South Wales government and the Sydney organising committee produced a joint submission for the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on Olympic related words and symbols. In that submission it stated that:

If the Commonwealth government fails to implement the proposed legislative protection, there could be a serious threat to the financial viability of the Sydney 2000 Games. . . The amount that sponsors will be willing to contribute to the Sydney 2000 Games will depend on the sponsors' degree of confidence that their sponsorship exclusivity will be protected by Australian laws.

The games organising committee would have a difficult time attracting such sponsors if it were not for tough laws preventing or deterring ambush marketing. According to the Sydney Morning Herald , there are about 850 companies interested in trying to get one of the 45 product licences. The interest is certainly there, but only because of the prospect of laws to protect companies once they get the contract.

In Atlanta, the committee has established a $10 million budget to police ambush marketing tactics and people or companies trying to make an illegal buck from the 1996 Olympics. The team they have set up for this includes private investigators, media monitors, volunteers and market researchers. Their job is to identify and stop ambushers and people engaging in the production of counterfeit Olympic paraphernalia. They have invested $10 million to give protection to licensed sponsors. Sport is a big commercial money‐spinner; the Olympics is the biggest game around and it is only going to get bigger. The worldwide television rights for the Montreal Olympics went for about $US32 million; the Atlanta rights have gone for $US900 million.

My home city of Townsville stepped into the Olympic spotlight last week when members of the Australian Olympic track and field team travelled north for training and acclimatisation sessions before heading off to Atlanta. Summer in Atlanta is hot and humid, and Townsville is an ideal Australian location for acclimatisation training—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly hot and humid.

—Certainly. Top Australian athletes Steve Monaghetti, Lisa Ondieki and sprinter Rod Mapstone are just some of the people who have spent time in Townsville recently—as well as a Mr Peter Slipper—as part of the preparation for Atlanta.

BREAK.PARA: James Cook University's sports science department specialises in the effects of hot and humid weather on sportsmen and sportswomen. The head of the sports department, Dr Robert Griffiths, said that JCU had been able to offer the Atlanta‐bound athletes advanced blood analysis technology. This monitors their bodies during training and their recovery rates after extensive training in the challenging climate.

James Cook's sports science department will be a key link in making Townsville an international centre for acclimatisation research and training. Dr Griffiths said that the department has been in close contact with the Australian Institute of Sport and has been able to offer valuable input, based on sophisticated blood test results, of the effects of heat and stress on athletes. Dr Griffiths has also expressed his interest in extending the department's facilities to other areas, such as the Australian Defence Force. The rigorous training they go through could be enhanced through the use of the facilities at the neighbouring James Cook University.

While the vast majority of people are in favour of this bill, some groups have argued against it, saying that there is no way to accurately measure whether these seemingly anti‐competitive laws are of real benefit. Surely, they say, it would be more lucrative to open competition up to everyone and allow all business to benefit from being able to use the Olympic Games names, phrases and images. I do not think so.

We all have to realise that, in the lead‐up to the Sydney Olympic Games, Australian businesses and tourism are going to benefit regardless. They will continue to benefit, although not at the same level, when the Games have passed to another country. No matter how hard we try, we cannot force tourists and visitors coming to Australia to shop in one shop, buy one label of clothing, eat at one food outlet, or use the film of one company.

The tens of thousands of tourists who will flood into every city in Australia will have to eat food, buy clothing, watch television, take pictures, travel to and from places, and they will do it through a multitude of different companies and businesses. The major sponsors will hold a special position, but then they have invested the money. This bill protects that investment. I commend the bill to the Main Committee and look forward to its recommendation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly, Jackie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The original modern Olympic Games organised by Pierre de Coubertin in 1896 was attended by 311 athletes from 13 countries who competed in 43 events in nine sports. At the Atlanta Games from 19 July until 4 August this year, 10,768 athletes from 197 countries will compete in over 600 events, 37 disciplines, and 26 sports. Some 40,000 volunteers will look after two million visitors and 11 million ticket holders. Some 140,580 rooms will be cleaned, 8,679 kilometres of toilet paper will be used, 727,272 kilograms of linen will be laundered—that is a stack about 4.8 kilometres high—and 110,200 towels will be used. Some two million soft drinks will be sold, and 890 litres of steak sauce, 950,000 apples, 30 kilometres of aluminium foil, 3½ million serviettes and 90 kilograms of garlic will be used.

SPEECH.PARA: From its humble beginnings in Athens, the modern Olympic Games has become a major commercial event. To ignore this commercial reality is to commit your bureaucracy to years of debt, as Montreal did in 1976. The city of Montreal will be paying off the 1976 games well into the next century: great games, but a financial disaster. In fact, the result was so bad for the IOC that they had great difficulty in attracting cities to bid for the 1984 games. Luckily, LA came to the rescue and we had the 1984 games which set the scene for the games today.

BREAK.PARA: The IOC has three aims: firstly, to ensure the regular celebration of the games, to make sure that they actually occur; secondly, to make them increasingly perfect, more and more worthy of their glorious past and in keeping with the high ideals that inspired those who revived the games; and, thirdly, to encourage and organise all events, taking all steps likely to lead modern athletes along the right lines.

TALK.START.PARA: —And win as many medals as possible.

—That is our aim. In order to ensure the continued celebration of the games all over the world and not just in large nations, a commercial approach was taken to the LA Olympics. The sporting, commercial and financial success of the LA Olympics ensured the event for years to come. Therefore, this parliament must do everything in its power to ensure the financial success of the Sydney Games in the year 2000. Failure to do this would discourage other cities from holding the games. To make the games even better and more and more worthy of their glorious past, and to organise all events and accommodate the growing number of athletes and events—the number of athletes has grown from 300 in 1896 to over 10,000 in the 23 times that the games have been held—is going to take more and more money, so protection of all areas of revenue is important.

BREAK.PARA: Before potential sponsors commit themselves to pay about $40 million per category for exclusive rights, we need to assure them that they are protected from ambush or parasitic marketing practices by commercial rivals. The image we must give to international businesses is that we are up to speed on current business practices and marketing techniques such as those covered by this bill. It is said in advertising that you never get a second chance to make a first impression, and the hosting of the games will introduce many overseas companies to the Australian market for the first time.

It must be remembered that the people of New South Wales are committed to covering the costs of the games and, in effect, have purchased the product of the Olympic Games for a short period. We must ensure that they are able to maximise their returns from the valuable product, and the Olympic Games insignia, as a marketing device, are very valuable assets. We must continue to display the level of professionalism and strategic foresight displayed by Mr John Fahey and his team in the successful bid to host the Olympics.

We must prepare ourselves to harvest the fruits of such a boon, and the Sydney 2000 Games (Indicia and Images) Protection Bill 1996 is just such a measure. The bill will contribute to the success of these games and help to protect the citizens of New South Wales and the athletes of Australia. It is important that we do not place the people of Sydney and New South Wales under unnecessary financial burdens as a result of the Olympics. The New South Wales government has committed itself to picking up the tab for many shortfalls from SOCOG's funding; we do not want to be like the citizens of Montreal after the year 2000. The hosting of the Olympic Games is a big business and, as an international event, many overseas companies will be interested in sponsorship deals with SOCOG. These deals will go a long way to covering the more than $3 billion needed to stage the games.

The people of Sydney will benefit greatly from the boost to infrastructure that will result from our hosting of the games. I am happy to say that the people of Lindsay will be hosting the rowing events at the Penrith Lakes and the Nepean River is the training venue for the rowing teams. In Penrith, we have the fastest growing junior basketball region in the state of New South Wales. Therefore, our area would make a great location for one of the basketball venues. The young people of Lindsay would love to see the basketballers of the US dream team in our area. Such infrastructure is invaluable for a community such as ours and the Olympic Games give the people of Lindsay the unique opportunity to be involved in the greatest international sporting event in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are well represented in parliament also.

—That is right, they are. The Sydney Games will allow the people of Lindsay the opportunity to present our area as a wonderful tourist destination to the people of Australia and to the world. The international visitors and worldwide television audience will have the pleasure of watching events held in our area and see the beauty of the Nepean River against the backdrop of the imposing Blue Mountains escarpment.

BREAK.PARA: What of the athletes themselves? The definition of `amateur' has gone by the board. The training required to reach Olympic standard today is almost full‐time. The commitment and sacrifice is huge and the athletes should be able to realise financial reward for their efforts. All too often we lose talented young athletes in their late teens or early twenties because they can no longer rely on parental support; they must support themselves. They must look to their future careers. All too often their chosen sport is unable to provide their pay cheque. They find themselves turning to other avenues and other careers in order to get a pay cheque.

I know, because in 1988 I was faced with a similar decision. I was a struggling athlete. I had represented Australia at the senior B level and I had dreamed of representing Australia in Seoul. That was my ambition for about two years. I had a full‐time job. I was spending most of my income on my rowing equipment. I was studying part-time to keep my university studies relevant and I was training five hours a day. So was the rest of my crew. We were not amateurs and we did not get AIS sponsorship. In 1988 we won a national title, only to be told there were insufficient funds to send a women's team to the lead‐up regattas, let alone to the Olympics in Seoul. I left rowing to follow a military career: I needed the pay cheque.

But I still have the dream that the Olympics will be the battlefield of the future, that nations will sort out their differences and aggressions on the sporting fields and abide by the umpire's decision. It is possible to use the Olympics for political ends and, except for the Munich Games, such exercising of political will does not have the enormous cost to human life that military action does. Winning an Olympic medal brings great kudos to your country. To give our athletes the best chance of reaching the world No. 1 ranking in their sport we must provide all the financial assistance we can. We need to encourage and safeguard sponsors' rights and promote private investment in our games and our athletes. The more young sportsmen who can make a living out of their sport instead of a military career, the closer to my dream we will be.

This bill is the start of financially rewarding careers in sport in Australia. May I remind the House of an Olympic motto: the most important thing in the Olympic Games is not to win, but to take part. Do not let us take financial constraints as any reason for athletes not to be able to participate at this level.

The most important thing in life is not the triumph but the struggle. The physical activity of our young and upcoming athletes teaches them the discipline that they can maintain right throughout life. The essential thing is not to have conquered but to have fought well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr WARWICK SMITH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I might just take the opportunity to sum up on behalf of the minister who is absent launching a spaceship somewhere. I thank those who have contributed to the debate. I have listened to the contributions of Mr Martin, Mr Kerr, Mr Lindsay and Miss Kelly. Mr Martin was particularly positive about the legislation. Mr Kerr told an interesting story about his High Court appearances. He won the case but, because the decision was made well after the bicentenary, he was unable to get the benefit for his clients. But particularly I want to thank Mr Lindsay and Miss Kelly. Mr Lindsay indicated in his remarks that the Olympic Games can be an opportunity for a broad benefit for all Australia. What has happened in sports medicine at James Cook University in Townsville with the visiting Olympians who went there for climate activity prior to going to Atlanta is an indication of what can happen in the Sydney 2000 Games. We must ensure that all areas of Australia are going to be able to participate in some positive way and that those communities are going to get the benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: It was particularly interesting to note that the TV rights—and this is the genus of what this legislation is about, providing marketing protection—in Montreal cost $32 million whereas in Atlanta they cost $900 million. Quite an extraordinary amount of money has now been paid. It is very much an international event. We ought not to forget here in Australia that when the games take place here and coincide with the change in the millennium that we are going to be showcasing Australia to the rest of the world through our sporting endeavours.

The honourable member for Lindsay made a very interesting contribution. I had not realised that she had committed so much to rowing. We are very lucky to have her in the House and her contribution was particularly positive. You will find, of course, there is some similarity between rowing and politics in that you look one way and go another. Do not take that as being a negative remark. I also was a rower but I did not last very long. I thought the contribution by the honourable member was very positive and I thank her for that.

The bill, as all speakers pointed out, will provide significant protection for the 2000 Games. It is particularly important, as I have said and as did the minister, to have this done at such an expeditious time in advance of Atlanta. The whole issue of protecting the games licensing revenue from ambush marketing was originally brought to the parliament by Senator Ian Campbell, a Western Australian senator who prior to the election was also shadow minister for sport. He moved a motion that the matter be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs back in June 1994. He is now the parliamentary secretary in this area.

It was through that initiative that this legislation came about. The committee was chaired by another Western Australian lawyer, Senator Chris Ellison, and it brought down a unanimous report supporting the introduction of this legislation to protect the games revenue from ambush marketing and here we are in 1996 putting it into effect through the committee process with a report now to the House of Representatives.

The government has been particularly conscious, in preparing the legislation, to give the games organisers the best possible protection without unduly inhibiting the legitimate operations of business. There is always a fine balance to be struck. We believe we have got it right. As I mentioned in my speech, there may be a necessity to bring in some further amendments to refine the matter but at this stage we think we have got it about right.

A number of commercial firms have been using the word `Olympic' as a business name and as a trademark for many years. This legislation is not about stopping traders from continuing with those legitimate uses. Traders may not, however, use the word in a way as to suggest a connection with the games unless they are duly licensed. Indeed, the member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) gave us some examples of what had taken place yesterday with the 45 licences that have been issued.

We wanted to make sure that there was a proper balance between the rights of the games organisers to protect that licensing revenue and the existing rights of members of the public and the wider business community. We believe that that protection provided by the bill will complement and enhance the protective measures already in place under Australia's current intellectual property laws and that it will help to ensure that a good budget outcome is achieved for the Sydney 2000 Games.

I pay tribute to the people in the minister's department in the intellectual property law area who had the prime responsibility for preparing this legislation. It is complex. There is keen interest in the definitional aspects and I think they have done a particularly good job. With those words, I thank again those who have contributed to a very positive debate and discussion of this matter. On behalf of the absent minister I can say that I hope that this matter can now proceed to the House of Representatives without amendment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN SPORTS DRUG AGENCY AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 June, on motion by Mr Warwick Smith:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —While we are in the mood for taking a very bipartisan approach to all matters associated with sport generally, let me indicate to the honourable the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government (Mr Warwick Smith) at the outset that the opposition wholeheartedly supports this particular legislation, the Australian Sports Drug Agency Amendment Bill 1996, as well. I am particularly delighted to be speaking in support of the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Ever since the Australian Sports Drug Agency was established in 1990, each time some legislation has come before this parliament I have taken an opportunity to speak in support of it. I have done so because at the time when there was a Senate committee—or it might even have been the drugs in sport inquiry, which was chaired by Senator John Black from Queensland—I was chairing another inquiry in the House of Representatives into the funding and administration of sport.

There was a degree of overlap in there, and occasionally there was a little bit of confusion about which committee was actually responsible for what part. But at the end of the day, the drugs in sport report, which came down in May 1990, saw the Australian Sports Drug Agency established. In the Department of the Parliamentary Library Parliamentary Research Service brief, Bills Digest No. 103 of 1995‐96, entitled `The Australian Sports Drug Agency Amendment Bill 1996'—and I go to that length so that I am not accused of stealing anybody else's words here—it indicates on page 2 that ASDA's mission is to ensure that Australian athletes are able to compete in sport which is free from banned doping practices. The agency's vision is to be one of the leading sports agencies in the world and to achieve excellence as a small statutory authority.

BREAK.PARA: I have to say from personal experience—not by being tested, but by involvement through my rugby league club, through the rugby league generally and through a number of other sports—that that vision has been achieved now and is appropriate, and that its mission is also being achieved. As an organisation, it is at the leading edge and one which the rest of the world could look to. It is not a secret, and I am not saying anything to anybody in this room that is not already known, that Australians have always prided themselves on their athleticism, their love of sport and the fact that they had always wanted to see that they were competing on equal and drug‐free terms.

One of the things that we have always championed in this country is drug‐free sport. We have seen some fairly famous cases involving Australians where our credentials in this area have been open to scrutiny. The drugs in sport inquiry was largely started because of an Australian athlete who maintained that the caffeine level in his body was related to his intake of several cups of coffee before he participated in his event. As a result of that there were all sorts of activities undertaken at the time.

Most recently we have seen the Sam Riley case. Could you ever take a more Australian Australian, someone as dedicated as Sam Riley, somebody as a role model, and say that simply because she took a headache tablet that contained a banned substance, she deserved to be banned? Incidentally, as I understand it, the substance was not performance enhancing but was, in fact, exactly the opposite. It was something designed to slow down performance. Yet she was faced at one stage with a possible ban, and we have seen a ban being imposed on her coach.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is outrageous.

—Given that Australia has been such a vocal opponent of drugs in sport, calling for testing when we saw the pictures of the Chinese swimming team, for example—I would not mind a couple of them playing for the Illawarra Steelers as front rowers, but they were swimmers—

—When we saw them, we were actually critical of that. There is a view around that suggests that the international authorities thought that because an Australian was involved in this, they should make an example of her—`Let us just see how the Australians like it when a particular ruling is given against them'. I hope that the international authorities are bigger than that.

BREAK.PARA: It is unfortunate that Sam's swimming coach has got to suffer that ban. It has been reduced, I know, but he still has that ban. Fortunately, he is still able to coach. But, whilst he might be in Atlanta, he is not going to be poolside, and that is a great shame. Fortunately for Australia, and fortunately for Sam Riley, she has been able to get above this and put it behind her. She is training extremely well. She was given an Order of Australia award in the recent announcements, which I think is a great recognition of a superb Australian. Yet she has had to go through so much.

The point is that what we in this country have done is matched the rhetoric of our absolute opposition to drugs in sport with some positive action. The government is to be commended for bringing this bill forward, because what it is doing is enhancing our ability to test not only Australian athletes but also those from overseas countries, and to put into place a number of arrangements which perhaps have existed in an informal sense.

In no way are we talking about infringing on the rights of athletes in some way. That is not what this is about at all. In fact, it is very clearly set out in the legislative base. Going through the clauses, one finds that it talks about the techniques of sample taking; who does the testing; if there is a positive test, how that is reported; processes so that, if someone has an intellectual disability of some kind, whoever is the guardian or parent is given the results of those tests; and so on. All of that is captured in here so that the rights of athletes are protected.

What we are doing is actually extending the ability of the Australian Sports Drug Agency to do what it does best: that is, ensure that people in all forms of sport in this country—from the highest competitive level to the most basic level—compete equally against each other, so that whoever wins the gold does so on the basis of natural ability and natural talent. That is something that we should all be delighted about.

As I have mentioned, I have had involvement with ASDA. On a number of occasions they came to check out, at random, clubs that are participating in the Australian Rugby League competition. Of course, my club—the Illawarra Steelers, of which I am still a director—is occasionally subjected to those testing procedures, and we see the ASDA people down in the dressing sheds waiting for the appropriate people to test. That is extended not only to the Australian Rugby League but also to the AFL, the National Soccer League, the National Basketball League and the Uncle Toby's Professional Ironman and Ironwoman Super Series.

That is important. As a parent, somebody who has kids involved in sport or somebody who is coaching a sporting team at home, what you want are role models who are going to be there as competitive athletes: people who are going to be out there striving, training hard and showing what it is like to be a competitive athlete without having to rely on banned substances to get across the line first. That is the sort of thing that we should be holding up to people, not the likes of failed pop stars who come back to Australia and say that they like taking drugs. That is not the sort of role model we are talking about. What we are talking about are Australian athletes—people like Sam Riley—who are out there and are clearly the sorts of role models that we want our children to emulate.

In terms of ASDA and its international initiatives, to again go to the brief provided by the Parliamentary Library, on page 3 there is a whole series of arrangements with foreign anti‐doping bodies which have been approved under the principal act. They are required to maintain lists of who they are actually working with, and they are listed here: the British Council Doping Control Unit, the Canadian Centre for Drug‐Free Sport, the New Zealand Sports Drug Agency and International Doping Tests Management.

I notice that we are also assisting China, at the present moment, in developing its anti‐doping policies and testing procedures. I think that is quite appropriate. In fact, sport can be a very useful tool in assisting with the democratisation of countries where, perhaps, there are some concerns. I am not specifically talking about China in this case. Basically, if people in a sporting community understand—through coming to international meets and so on—the aspirations of other athletes and the types of environments in which other athletes participate, and see the freedoms that are involved, that can assist with political democratisation in their countries in a broader sense. I think that is quite an appropriate thing to do.

The fact that we in Australia have been able to assist so widely in developing drug testing programs, signing memoranda with a whole range of governments around the world to assist in that and entering into intergovernmental agreements is a great tribute to this country, to the past government and, certainly, to the present government that has taken these initiatives in bringing this legislation forward now.

I am not going to go into all the provisions that are contained in this because they have been adequately covered by the minister in his second reading speech. I would simply say, though, that we have to be ever vigilant. I say that because very recently—and I am not sure if honourable members saw this—a survey was done again of Australia's leading athletes and questions were put to them about drug usage. The one of greatest concern to me was that a very high proportion of Australia's leading athletes indicated that they had actually thought about using performance enhancing drugs. They had given it some thought because, like all athletes, like anybody in any business, if you are striving to be number one in what you want to do, clearly you make sacrifices.
