This bill comes—and I do not say this disrespectfully—from the prosecutorial side of things, so it is important to get the balance and the experience from the other side of the bar table. My particular experience involved a case that left an indelible mark on me and this has necessarily excited my interest in this particular bill. I seek leave to table the case. I do not want to mention it by name. I will refer to it as `M', if I may, Mr Deputy Speaker.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to refer as quickly as I can to elements of that case and then relate it to the bill before the House. In that particular case, there was a major drug operation in Queensland. As a result of that major operation, to my knowledge only one person was netted, and that was M. The operation extended over many months. It cost the community hundreds of thousands of dollars and the result that was produced was less than satisfactory.

SPEECH.PARA: Of the person M for whom I appeared, I can only say this. Having spent numerous hours with the person when I was in conference with her and so forth, I thought I had heard it all before until she came to give her evidence on the voir dire. Hearing her evidence in chief on the voir dire was enough to move me to tears, because it was an unbelievable story. The case extract does not fully illustrate it, but it illustrates it to a large extent.

I am concerned that this is the sort of case that might be caught by the bill. In that particular case, the undercover police officer received an indemnity from the Attorney‐General. The indemnity said this:
that no prosecution or indictment will be brought or continued against R—
R being the undercover police officer—

BREAK.PARA: in respect of any act or omission reasonably and necessarily done or made by him in the execution of his duty as a police officer and in the course of the police operation codenamed—
I will leave that out—
and I do hereby indemnify him accordingly.

By way of background, the accused gave evidence on the voir dire. The voir dire is a trial within a trial. It is where the judge has to determine admissibility. This is important in the context of the bill. The defendant, or the accused, had to satisfy on the balance of probabilities that the evidence was unfair—in other words, that the evidence that was to be adduced against her was unfair, so therefore, she had to satisfy the judge on the balance of probabilities that it ought to be excluded.

It is important to bear that in mind. As I understand the law even now—and the law that will apply here—if the same situation arises, the onus on the voir dire will be with the defendant. It is all very well to say, `But ultimately, it is "beyond reasonable doubt"'. But if you cannot get past the voir dire, you go into the trial on the evidence. In the case of people who are caught in these nets, they frequently have a criminal history as long as your arm. Once they are raising unfairness and putting in issue the credit of the police officer, their history comes before the jury and they are gone. They are gone! The jury are not interested any more in the defence side of the case. That is the problem. It does concern me.

This woman was 36 years of age at the time of this operation. She was introduced to marijuana when she was 13 and later to speed and acid. She was introduced to heroin when she went to university. She tried on numerous occasions to detoxify; she made a suicide attempt when she was 20. Her attempts to detoxify led to her being introduced to other drugs. She had an injury to her back, exacerbated by a car accident. The degree of pain was intolerable; this led her back to drugs. She had a sexual attack upon her where she was dropped on her head at Bondi. She suffered violently from pelvic problems—this was at the time of the trial. She had had a number of violent relationships with men. She had a history of prostitution, but she had, in her earlier days, excelled as a student. She had great potential but was held back. She had been involved with people who had died over the years from drugs and so forth, but she came to Queensland to get away from the drugs.

In the latter part of 1988, she had an accident in which she hit a little boy. The consequences of that were not very serious, but that led her to try to commit suicide again, because this is the way she was—constantly in depression. She took up with a friend who had also been in drugs, and this friend was then approached by the undercover police officer. There was no suggestion that she was dealing in drugs in any way, shape or form, other than that she used to smoke marijuana for pain. That is what she did. On a scale of one to 10, her pain level was somewhere about eight all the time. That was the medical evidence. So what do you do when you are a drug addict, or a former drug addict, and you have that sort of pain problem?

She was on methadone at the time, and she was going to university, trying to re‐establish her life. Then this individual came into her life. This individual, on the pretext that he was dying of cancer and was a small‐time dealer, fed his way into her life. She fell in love with him, and she would do anything that he said. So he inveigled her; he pressured her; he would constantly provide marijuana to her to smoke. Because the story seemed to hang together, it went on.

In the meantime, unbeknown to the undercover police officer—she did not know he was undercover, of course—she was seeing a psychologist and was saying quite the opposite: `He is trying to get me into drugs. He is trying to get me drugs. I do not want to, but I love him.' All of that evidence came out as part of it. It was a thoroughly dreadful case.

His Honour made the following findings. She had been a heroin addict for many years in Sydney and moved to try to overcome it. She had serious medical, psychiatric and psychological problems, for which she had received treatment and counselling prior to 1989 and for which she was still receiving treatment. She had formed a close association with another drug addict, F, because it was difficult to find other social contacts with people who had not had a background similar to hers. She had used marijuana primarily to cope with her severe medical, psychiatric and psychological problems. She was strongly dependent on other people and prone to depression, with suicidal tendencies. She had taken a number of measures to deal with her problem. She had been a participant in the work of the alcohol and drug dependency unit and had resumed her university studies.

These matters were known, at least to a substantial degree, by the undercover police officer. He cultivated the friendship, His Honour found, through this other person and sought to promote the friendship through frequent social contacts. The emotional attachment started. Cannabis was used frequently on those contacts. So it goes on. But time is eluding me.

As a result of that, she was used to obtain a source of supply of cocaine in Sydney. One of most hideous aspects of all of this was that when this cocaine was brought back he gave her a cut of that cocaine. Was that necessary to the indemnity? I would say absolutely not, and I believe the man should have been charged with an offence, because it was not necessary to the indemnity to give her a cut. I further say—although His Honour did not find this—that I am absolutely satisfied that heroin was also supplied to her. So, by virtue of all of that evidence, His Honour found it was unfair, and he excluded all of the relevant evidence. So, ultimately, she walked from the court. I hope she has resumed her life to a large extent. The last time I heard, she had done that, after a lot of difficulty getting over all of this and the shock, too, of being told that this person she was in love with was actually a police officer who had been using her for nearly a year.
I will get to the bill very quickly now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to hear that.
—He is laying the foundation.

—I am laying the foundation. In the bill, in section 15I(2)(b)—I know it is in a different context from 15M—the words used are `the person would not otherwise have had the intent to commit that offence or an offence of that kind.' The word `would' is used, and I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to bear that in mind. The words `the intent' I have a bit of a problem with too. Should it say `an intent'? I will leave that aside for a moment. The words are again used in subsection (5) of that same section—`would not otherwise have had the intent'.

BREAK.PARA: We then come to this critical section, 15M, which relates to the certificate authorising a controlled operation. Part (b) of section 15M says:
the person targeted by the operation is likely to commit an offence . . .
I caution those who have presented this bill, and I do so with the greatest respect to those on both sides of the House who have expressed views on this, about the use of those words.

It is my submission that the word `would' is a far better word to use there. The reality is that the Mr Bigs are rarely, if ever, caught. We know that that is the intention. We know that is what we are trying to do. But, frequently, as happened in this case, it is the person at the very bottom—the broken‐down, sad, tragic person—who is caught in this web, and that is my concern. That then goes to the issues on the voir dire, and the onus of proof and the problems there. It is all very well to say, `If you provide a test like that, the jump is too high'.

However, we have to have something that can rectify that onus of proof problem. Indeed, it may be worthwhile considering whether the onus on the voir dire in a case such as this should be on the prosecution. That would go some way to alleviating the problem, again, on the balance of probabilities, as it always is. At the moment, it is on the defendant. Alternatively, we could look at the use of the word `would' in light of what, to me, seems a somewhat inconsistent use in the earlier section of the word `would'. I know that it is a separate area. It is a certificate in one area but, nonetheless, we seem to be departing slightly and we leave it open.

I think my time has run out but I do urge caution in relation to the matter. I have reservations. I believe the member for Banks has identified in broad terms that we have to monitor it carefully. But, bear in mind, as I said before, that people like M could be caught in the same situation. At the end of these operations, where hundreds of thousands of dollars have been spent, we all know that someone has to be prosecuted, and frequently it is that person.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sercombe) adjourned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 2 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the (a) reported and (b) estimated number of diabetics in Australia.
(2) What is the estimated total cost of diabetes to Australia.
(3) What sum does the Commonwealth provide to each State and Territory to combat diabetes.
(4) What assistance does the Commonwealth provide to Diabetes Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The 1989 National Health Survey conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) estimated the prevalence of diabetes in all ages to be 1.5%1. A more recent ABS survey of Australians aged 18 years and over, indicated the prevalence of diabetes at 3.8% for all adults2. The majority (90%) of Australians with diabetes suffer from non‐insulin dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM or Type 2 diabetes). Diabetes is likely to affect 900,000 Australians by 2000 and 1.5 million Australians by 20103.

(2) Nationally, the health care and other costs associated with diabetes were estimated to be $126.13 million in 1989‐90. When the additional estimated costs of diabetes‐related complications are taken into account, this figure almost doubles to $247.88 million4. These figures include public and private health care costs, such as hospital, general practitioners, medical specialists, pharmaceuticals and other supplies, and allied health care such as podiatry and dietetics, as well as indirect costs, such as foregone income, time off work and costs to carers.

(3) Although the Commonwealth does not provide direct funding to the States and Territories to combat diabetes, it funds a number of activities aimed at preventing the onset of diabetes and reducing the impact of complications. This includes:

Commonwealth Government subsidies in respect of insulin, testing strips and syringes which currently represent an average Government outlay in excess of $900 per annum for each person with diabetes who uses insulin;
Funding through Medicare for specialist and general practitioner services;
Approximately $5.25 million provided through the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) for 77 researcher‐initiated research projects into diabetes and related issues in 1996;

Approximately $1.5 million for twenty projects funded through the Divisions of General Practice since May 1995. The projects aim to improve the management of diabetes through a range of activities including upskilling general practitioners, dietary clinics, access to shared care, and health promotion and education;

Three rural health projects relating to diabetes have received funding of approximately $458,000 to provide diabetes management and education training for health care professionals and health workers in rural areas.

The Government has developed a comprehensive and strategic National Diabetes Action Plan as outlined in our policy document "Health Through out Life". Implementation will take considerable coordinated effort.

(4) The Commonwealth has provided assistance to Diabetes Australia through a grant of $44,726 through the Community Organisations' Support Program (COSP) to the Australian Diabetes Society (the scientific and medical division of Diabetes Australia) to develop a Resource Manual on Diabetes Programs for people of non‐English speaking backgrounds.

The Commonwealth also provides funding to Diabetes Australia to administer the National Diabetic Services Scheme (NDSS). This scheme provides subsidised blood and urine glucose testing strips and syringes for use by registered persons with diabetes. $22.5 million was provided in 1994‐95.
1. Nutbeam D, Thomas M & Wise M. National Action Plan: Diabetes to the Year 2000 and Beyond. The Australian Diabetes Society 1993.
2. Australian Bureau of Statistics. Population Survey Monitor. February 1994.
3. McCarty D, Zimmet P, et al. National Action Plan: Diabetes to the Year 2000—The rise and rise of Diabetes in Australia 1996. International Diabetes Institute 1996.
4. Carter R, Mathers C, et al. The cost of diet‐related disease in Australia. Australian Institute of Health and Welfare 1992.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 20 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that (a) prostate cancer is the third most common cause of death from cancer among Australian men, (b) the lifetime risk of developing prostate cancer is 1 in 23 and (c) the incidence of prostate cancer is increasing.

(2) Was the need for screening measures referred to the Australian Health Technology Advisory Committee (AHTAC) for its consideration in May 1995; if so (a) was AHTAC expected to report its findings in late 1995 and (b) has AHTAC reported; if so when will its findings be released publicly; if not (i) why not and (ii) when will it report.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)(a) Prostate cancer is the second most common cause of death from cancer among Australian men, after lung cancer. In 1994, 2,590 Australian men died of prostate cancer and it is estimated that there were 2,810 deaths in 1995.

(b) The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare's report Cancer in Australia 1989‐1990 (with projections to 1995) , which was released in April 1996, estimates the lifetime risk of developing prostate cancer as 1 in 18.

(c) The reported incidence of prostate cancer is rising. In 1990, the latest year for which national figures are available, 5,753 new cases of prostate cancer were reported. Where data are available for individual States, the reported incidence of prostate cancer has doubled over the last five years. The increase in reported incidence of prostate cancer is thought to be largely due to developments in prostate cancer detection methods in recent years, such as the Prostate Specific Antigen (PSA) test.

(2) In April 1995, the Australian Health Technology Advisory Committee (AHTAC) was requested by the then Minister for Human Services and Health to review the evidence on the benefits, risks and costs of prostate cancer screening.

(a) It was originally expected that the review would be completed by the end of 1995. However, in order to produce a comprehensive review taking into account the latest available data, AHTAC required more time to complete its report. In producing its report, AHTAC has undertaken a comprehensive review of the scientific literature, current practice and the positions of medical professional bodies on prostate cancer screening; consulted widely inviting public submissions through the national press and by approaching interested organisations and individuals; examined social aspects and community attitudes; and incorporated the most recent available data on prostate cancer incidence and mortality in Australia.
(b) AHTAC reported in May 1996 and I am currently considering AHTAC's recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 21 May 1996:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Are insurers able to delay making payments to successful claimants under provisions in the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Act 1995.

(2) Is interest payable on the sum awarded if an insurer ceases payment of workers' compensation at the date of an award in favour of a claimant under the Act and delays payment of the sum awarded: if not, why not; if so, what measures will the Government take to ensure that interest is paid from the date of the award bringing the Act into line with relevant provisions in various Australian Supreme Court Acts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Act 1995 (the Act), insurers are not permitted to pay to their clients any amount of compensation that has been arrived at either by way of agreement between the parties or following a judgement of a court, until the Commonwealth has been refunded the Medicare and/or nursing home benefits that have been paid as a result of the compensation claim.
(2) Notwithstanding the above, the insurer may be required to pay interest to the claimant where the time limits set by a court are exceeded.

(3) The Act specifically excludes the Commonwealth from any liability for interest in circumstances where there is a delay in compensation payments being made. The reason being that the Act has been constructed in such a way that insurers can notify the Health Insurance Commission as soon as a claim has been made and can obtain a Notice of Charge before the case is finalised. Where a Notice of Charge is obtained before a judgment or settlement there need be no delay in the payment of compensation monies.

(4) However, there have been delays, particularly in New South Wales, in the issuance of the final notices by the Health Insurance Commission, following the introduction of the scheme. This final notice (the Notice of Charge) is the clearance required by the insurer in order to be able to pay out to the claimant the balance of the compensation monies.

(5) The Health Insurance Commission advises that the average time taken to issue a Notice of Charge varies from two weeks in Tasmania and Queensland to eight weeks in New South Wales. The HIC has a maximum of three months within which to issue the Notice of Charge following receipt by it of a Notice of Judgment or Settlement.

(6) The principal reason for the Health Insurance Commission's current inability to produce the Notice of Charge at much shorter time frames than those mentioned above is the much larger than anticipated volume of claims which were finalised soon after the commencement of the Act (1 February 1996) which the Health Insurance Commission has had to process.
(7) To reduce its processing time, the Health Insurance Commission is putting staff on overtime and engaging additional (temporary) staff.

(8) On 21 May 1996, I met with the New South Wales Bar Association, the Insurance Council of Australia and the Law Society of New South Wales to discuss the delays. We have reached broad agreement as to how this can be corrected, with all parties acknowledging it is going to require legislation.

(9) To that end, the Government is intending to introduce a Bill into Parliament later in the Winter sittings. We expect the level of cooperation that has been displayed by the lawyers and insurers so far in working towards a solution will mean that the Government can overcome the problems with the current Act to everyone's satisfaction.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mr Pyne

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 30 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the difficulty some sufferers of the genetic disorder cystic fibrosis are experiencing in attaining Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme eligibility for the medication Pulmozyme.
(2) Is eligibility based on a requirement of 10 per cent improvement within one month; if so, will the Government alter the requirement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My attention has not been drawn to the difficulties cystic fibrosis sufferers have been experiencing in gaining access to the drug Pulmozyme under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

Pulmozyme is available as a pharmaceutical benefit in accordance with guidelines developed by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee following discussions with the Australian Cystic Fibrosis Associations Federation and specialists in the treatment of cystic fibrosis. The drug is supplied from the out‐patient departments of public hospitals after patients have been assessed at (or in association with) cystic fibrosis clinics. PBS subsidy commenced from 1 January this year.
I am not aware of complaints from the Federation or physicians that the current guidelines are no longer appropriate.

(2) Yes. For PBS subsidy the patient needs to demonstrate a 10% improvement in lung function (FEV1—forced expiratory volume in one second) after an initial trial of up to four weeks treatment at the recommended dose. This is because the clinical effectiveness of the drug is marginal and the cost high. The clinical evidence shows that the drug is most beneficial (and most cost effective) in the group of patients who achieve a response to initial treatment of at least 10% improvement in FEV1.

The Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee recommendation was based on clinical evidence submitted by the sponsor and a subsequent meeting with the Cystic Fibrosis Association and respiratory physicians. It is unlikely that this requirement will change unless further clinical evidence is provided to show that the drug is similarly effective in other patient categories.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 30 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Are major delays occurring in the settlement of workers' compensation claims following the passage of health legislation in 1995; if so, (a) why and (b) what is he doing to minimise the delays.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There have been complaints from both insurers and claimants of delays, particularly in New South Wales, in the issuance of Notices of Charge in respect of all types of compensation claims under the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Act 1995 (the Act). A Notice of Charge specifies the amount of Medicare and/or nursing home care benefits refundable to the Commonwealth by the claimant out of the claimant's compensation monies. The amount on the Notice of Charge must be paid before they are able to pay out to the claimant the balance of the compensation monies.

(2) The Health Insurance Commission advises that the average time taken to issue a Notice of Charge varies from two weeks in Tasmania and Queensland to eight weeks in New South Wales. The Health Insurance Commission has a maximum of three months within which to issue the Notice of Charge following receipt by it of a Notice of Judgment or Settlement.

(3) The principal reason for the Health Insurance Commission's current inability to produce the Notice of Charge at much shorter time frames than those mentioned above is the much larger than anticipated volume of claims which were finalised soon after the commencement of the Act (1 February 1996) which the Health Insurance Commission has had to process.
(4) To reduce its processing time, the Health Insurance Commission is putting staff on overtime and engaging additional (temporary) staff.

(5) On 21 May 1996, I met with the New South Wales Bar Association, the Insurance Council of Australia and the Law Society of New South Wales to discuss the delays. We have reached broad agreement as to how this can be corrected, with all parties acknowledging it is going to require legislation.

(6) To that end, the Government is intending to introduce a Bill into Parliament later in the Winter sittings. We expect the level of cooperation that has been displayed by the lawyers and insurers so far in working towards a solution will mean that the Government can overcome the problems with the current Act to everyone's satisfaction.
